title: Why is it true that more nodes in an orbital result in a higher energy? - Quora

response.answer_text: In quantum mechanics, the kinetic energy of a quantum state is determined by the (real-space) curvature of the wavefunction. It should be visually recognizable that a shape with more nodes has more curvature than a shape with fewer. Think for a moment about a pair of plane-wave wavefunctions, with different wavelengths. From the de Broglie relations, the plane-wave with longer wavelength will have less momentum and therefore less kinetic energy. And it certainly has fewer nodes than the other, as well. The full argument is just a generalization of that point. You can consider a pair of real wavefunctions, for instance, which would represent bound states in one dimension. A Gaussian, say, and some polynomial times a Gaussian will have different kinetic energies, surely, with the zeros of the polynomial giving the nodes of that higher-energy wavefunction. You can brute-force solve for the expectation value of the kinetic energies of each wavefunction, but the physical reasoning is the same as for planewaves. Indeed, a sketch of a proof might use a Fourier transform of these real-space orbitals to expand them in planewaves; the state with more nodes will have significant contribution from smaller wavelengths than the simple Gaussian. I was working on a general proof, but it was taking a bit more time than I prefer for a single question for this website. Let me know if there’s anything unclear regarding the above.
